content.heading: Importance of Foundations in Construction
body: A foundation is the lowest part of a building structure that transfers the load of the building safely to the ground.
Foundations are essential for structural integrity, preventing settlement, and ensuring long-term durability.
points: Load Distribution – spreads the weight of the structure evenly across the soil.
Stability – anchors the structure, preventing tilting or collapse.
Prevents Settlement – reduces the risk of uneven sinking or cracking.
Moisture Protection – protects against groundwater and dampness.
Improved Durability – enhances the lifespan of the building.

content.heading: Types of Foundations
body: Foundations are mainly categorized into two types: Shallow Foundations and Deep Foundations. Each is chosen based on soil conditions, structure type, and load factors.

content.heading: Shallow Foundations
body: Shallow foundations are used when surface soil has adequate load-bearing capacity. They are economical and easy to construct.
points: Isolated Footing – supports a single column. Common in small buildings.
Combined Footing – supports two or more columns, used when they are close together.
Strip Footing – continuous footing under walls. Suitable for load-bearing walls.
Raft Foundation – a large concrete slab supporting multiple columns and walls. Ideal for weak soils.

content.heading: Deep Foundations
body: Deep foundations are used when surface soil is weak, and load must be transferred to deeper, stronger layers.
points: Pile Foundation – long, slender columns driven deep into the ground. Used in high-rise buildings and bridges.
Pier Foundation – vertical cylindrical supports constructed by excavating and concreting in place.
Caisson Foundation – watertight retaining structure, often used in underwater or bridge projects.

content.heading: How to Choose the Right Foundation
points: Type and weight of the structure
Surrounding conditions (like adjacent buildings or slope)

content.title: 2. Vastu for Residential Planning
content.content: Vastu Shastra guides room placement for harmony. Kitchen in SE, master bedroom SW, and entrance in NE are common practices.

content.title: 3. RCC Column, Beam and Slab Basics
content.content: Reinforced Concrete Cement (RCC) forms the skeleton of modern buildings. Proper lapping, cover, and bar bending are key for safety.

content.title: 4. Importance of Waterproofing
content.content: Leakages weaken structures. Common waterproofing includes brush coat, membrane, and chemical-based methods like Dr. Fixit.

content.title: 5. Brick vs Concrete Blocks
content.content: Bricks offer thermal insulation; blocks offer cost & speed. AAC blocks are light and popular in modern homes.

content.title: 6. Electrical Planning in Homes
content.content: Plan switchboards early. Use MCBs and ELCBs for safety. Mark TV, AC, and kitchen points before plastering.

content.title: 7. Types of Flooring Materials
content.content: Popular options include vitrified tiles, granite, marble, and wooden flooring. Vitrified tiles are cost-effective and durable.

content.title: 8. Plastering & Finishing Tips
content.content: Apply 2 layers—rough and smooth. Always cure for 7 days. Add chicken mesh at brick-RCC joints to prevent cracks.

content.title: 9. Site Safety Measures
content.content: Safety helmets, gloves, and netting are essential. Keep first-aid and signage on site. Supervision reduces accidents.

content.title: 10. Rainwater Harvesting Basics
content.content: Capture roof runoff using pipes and store in a sump. Add filters before storage. Helps recharge borewells and save water.
